title: Stress & Intimacy
description: Explore how life stress affects your intimate connection.

questions.text: When I'm stressed, my desire for intimacy usually...
choices: Decreases—I have less energy for it
Increases—it helps me feel connected
Stays about the same
Varies depending on the type of stress

therapeutic.rationale: Stress-desire patterns vary widely. Decrease-types need bandwidth; increase-types use intimacy to cope; steady-types aren't affected; variable-types depend on context. Misunderstanding your partner's pattern causes conflict during stress.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The increase-type may feel rejected by the decrease-type during stress; the decrease-type may feel pressured. Neither is wrong—understand each other's stress response.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared stress-desire pattern means you'll sync up during stressful times. This alignment helps during hard seasons.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What happens to your desire when you're stressed? Why do you think that is?

questions.text: During stressful seasons, I'd want us to...
choices: Give each other more grace about intimacy
Make intimacy a priority to stay connected
Talk about what we each need right now
Find low-effort ways to stay close

therapeutic.rationale: Stress season strategies differ. Grace-givers lower expectations; prioritizers maintain connection; talkers process needs; effort-adjusters find middle ground. Agreeing on your stress strategy helps during hard times.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The prioritizer may feel the grace-giver is giving up; the grace-giver may feel the prioritizer is adding pressure. Find your shared approach before stress hits.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared strategy makes navigating stressful seasons easier. You'll naturally respond similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you want to handle intimacy during stressful times? What would feel supportive?

questions.text: When stress affects our intimate connection, I tend to...
choices: Feel disappointed but understanding
Worry about the relationship
Accept it as temporary
Want to talk about how to reconnect

therapeutic.rationale: Responses to stress-affected intimacy reveal attachment. Disappointed-but-understanding types are secure; worriers are anxious; accepters are patient; talkers process actively. These responses shape recovery.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The worrier may need reassurance the accepter doesn't think to give; the talker may push conversations the disappointed partner doesn't need. Know each other's responses.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared response means you'll experience and process stress-affected intimacy similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when stress affects your intimate life? What do you need from your partner?

questions.text: The type of connection that helps me most during stress is...
choices: Physical closeness without pressure
Talking and emotional support
Acts of care and help
Space to manage my own stress

therapeutic.rationale: Stress support needs vary. Closeness-needers want physical presence; talkers need emotional processing; acts-needers want practical help; space-needers want autonomy. Giving the wrong support feels unsupportive.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The closeness-needer may feel rejected by the space-needer's withdrawal; the space-needer may feel smothered by physical pursuit. Ask: 'What kind of support do you need right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched stress support needs make comforting each other intuitive.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What kind of support helps you most when you're stressed? What doesn't help?

questions.text: After a stressful period, reconnecting intimately feels...
choices: Natural—we bounce back easily
Important—it helps us feel like us again
Something we need to be intentional about
Like it takes time to get back to normal

therapeutic.rationale: Reconnection patterns vary. Natural-bouncers recover quickly; importance-placers prioritize it; intentional types need effort; time-needers recover slowly. Understanding your pattern helps set expectations.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The natural-bouncer may not understand why their partner needs more time; the time-needer may feel pressured to reconnect before ready. Honor each other's pace.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared reconnection pattern means you'll recover from stressful seasons at similar rates.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you reconnect intimately after stress? What helps? What doesn't?
